prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: Québec Law—Termination of the Employment Contract

para.paratext: Upon the termination of employment, a number of events are triggered. Article 2095 C.C.Q. deals specifically with two of these events:

2095. An employer may not avail himself of a stipulation of non-competition if he has resiliated the contract without a serious reason or if he has himself given the employee such a reason for resiliating the contract.

First, in the event the employee is terminated without a serious reason (similar to the “without cause” standard in the rest of Canada), the employer will not be able to enforce a restrictive covenant that was agreed to between the parties, notwithstanding the validity of such clause. Moreover, some argue that an employer cannot require an employee to renounce his or her right to work during the period equivalent to the severance indemnity granted.

Article 2095 C.C.Q. refers to constructive dismissals as defined by the Supreme Court of Canada in Farber,[1] which originated in the Province of Québec. In such situations, the employer cannot argue that the employee put an end to the contract of employment in order to invoke the restrictive covenant. Of course, the employer may be acting in good faith in modifying the provisions of the employment contract, but a court may still conclude that a constructive dismissal occurred.
Farber v. Royal Trust Co. (1997), 145 D.L.R. (4th) 1, [1997] 1 S.C.R. 846.
